conclusion: Analyze the geometry and behavior of light in the semicircular glass brick.
The semicircular glass brick has a radius R and light rays strike the flat base at an angle π - γ.
The critical angle for total internal reflection is γ.
The angle of incidence θ_i at the flat base is π - γ.
The angle of incidence at the curved surface will be γ.
Light refracts at the curved surface according to Snell's Law.
Snell's Law: n_1 sin(θ_i) = n_2 sin(θ_r), where n_1 is the refractive index of air and n_2 is the refractive index of glass.
The critical angle γ is the angle beyond which total internal reflection occurs.
For light to pass through the base, the angle of incidence at the curved surface must be less than γ.
The light that passes through the base forms a circular segment on the base.
The width of this segment is found by considering the geometry of the semicircle and the angle of refraction.
Light rays passing through the base form a chord on the semicircle.
The chord length L is given by L = 2R sin(θ), where θ is the angle subtended by the chord at the center of the circle.
The angle θ is related to the critical angle γ.
Since light rays strike the base at π - γ, the angle subtended by the chord at the center is 2γ.
The width of the portion of the base through which light passes is L = 2R sin(γ).
